category: Supporting businesses to get back to normal
subcategory: Measures to support a gradual relaunch of work
background_info_description: COVID-19 had a negative impact upon many enterprises in Malta. In order to support such organisations, the major employer and professional associations in Malta have been conducting research amongst their members to determine the impact of COVID-19. The primary aim of this is to have an up to date picture of the impact upon members and to use this to inform the government whilst also using it to provide direction when drafting policy recommendations.
content_of_measure_description: Various employer associations have been conducting research amongst their members. The purpose of this data is to inform policy recommendations and for use during lobbying with government and other social partners. The Malta Employers Association (MEA) conducted its third COVID-19 survey amongst its members in September 2020. The survey had three aims:* To evaluate business performance by sector and company size; * To determine employers’ projections for the coming months; * To study the labour market potential in surviving the pandemic. Preliminary findings published by the MEA (September 2020) highlighted that 81% of organisations reported a loss of business since the start of the pandemic, with 45% of respondents reporting a loss of business of 45% or more. Almost half of respondents, however, reported that the situation was better between June and August than it was between March and May. 19% (45 organisations) reported making redundancies between June-August. 65% of organisations also reported that they have employees who are making use of teleworking Other related research has been conducted by the Malta Chamber of Commerce, Enterprise and Industry (known as the Malta Chamber) as well as by The Malta Chamber of SMEs. Research by the latter (July 2020) highlighted that sales levels, uncertainty, and employee wages were the greatest concerns for SMEs, that 13% of respondents had instigated redundancies due to COVID-19, and that government COVID-19 measures had been generally well received. Surveys have also been conducted by other professional groups that represent employers / self-employed professional workers, such as that conducted by the Chamber of Architects (Kamra tal-Periti).
use_of_measure_description: The individual research projects have been used for lobbying and to inform recommended policy direction. More specific information is unavailable.
involvement_of_social_partners_descripti: The surveys were designed by the specific employer's associations and then distributed amongst their members. The analysis and publication of these findings was also the remit of the specific employer associations. The findings were used primarily during discussions between the employer associations and government.

sources.title: Malta Employers Association - COVID-19 survey September 2020
sources.content: MEA Survey Preliminary Results,September 2020BusinessPerformanceduringCOVID-19�SURVEY, SEPTEMBER 2020MethodologyOnline Survey- Open & Ended Questions- One reply per user237 Respondants- 27th August - 4th September 2020- Different Sectors (incl. groups of companies)Out of 237 survey respondents, 22% of companies employ less than 10 employees, 39% employbetween 10-49 employees, 29% employ between 50-249 employees, 7% employ beween 250-499employees, and 4% employ more than 500 employees.Out of 237 respondents, 54% of the companies are geared for the domestic economy, whilst 18%are geared for export. 27% of respondents claim that their business is geared for both thedomestic economy and export.Effects of Covid-19 on BusinessOut of the 237 survey respondents, 81% experienced a loss of business, 3% experienced anincrease in business and 16% of respondents claim that COVID-19 is having no effect on theirbusiness operations.There is a slight decrease in 'loss of business' (-6%) and an increase in 'no effect' (+6%) fromprevious survey conducted in June 2020.Out of the 193 respondents that have claimed a loss of business, 12% registered a loss between 0-15%, 23% registered a loss between 15-30%, 19% registered a loss between 30-45%,  18%registered a loss between 45-60%, and 27% registered a loss of more than 60%.As expected, the hospitality sector is the most sector that have been affected - with 12% ofrespondents claiming that they have experienced a loss of business by more than 60%.  When asked about improvements during the last 3 months (when compared to Mar-May), 48% ofrespondents stated that they had improvements, 36% stated that business remained the same,and 16% stated that business performance was worse.Improvement in Business PerformanceCOVID-19: Second WaveWhen asked whether the second spike could have been avoided, 37% of survey respondents haveanswered in the affirmative, and another 59% stated 'Partially, yes'. 4% answered in thenegative.Redundancies81% of respondents state that they have not made any redundancies in their company. The other19%, amounting to 46 companies, have made some redundancies by different percentages – 85%by up to 25%; 9% by up to 50%; and 4% by up to 75%. The other 2% did not response thequestion. Expected redundancies in the next 3 monthsWhen asked if companies can see an increase in redundancies in the next three months (Sept-Nov,2020), 38% of respondents answered ‘No’. 19% of respondents answered ‘Yes’ and 43% are still'Undecided’.Government SupportWhen asked if companies will depend on extended government support in 2021, 44% ofrespondents claimed 'Yes', 16% claimed 'No' and 22% claimed 'Don't Know'. 17% of surveyrespondents do not qualify for any governmental support.Telework Arrangements65% of survey respondents have employees that are making use of teleworking arrangements.    Out of the 65% that answered 'Yes', 42% of respondents deem to keep the same and/or increaseteleworking arrangements following Covid-19. 33% of respondents will decrease the arrangementsthat have been introduced, and 20% of respondents are still undecided.   Opening of SchoolsPostponement of Investment Projects60% of survey respondents have not yet initiated any investment projects that have beenpostponed due to COVID-19. Out of this 60%, 11% stated that they will definitely be reactivingtheir projects within the next 12 months. 23% stated that they will definitely NOT be reactivingtheir projects within the coming 12 months, while another 36% are still unsure. Another 30% didnot answer the question.Major employment related mattersaffecting business due to COVID-19:Sense of instability and uncertaintyDemotivated employees Fear of returning to workLess cash in hand (struggling to pay salaries)Lack of skilled staff (recruitment issues)Permits of foreign nationalsIncrease in sick leaveQuarantine LeaveRecovery of Business Activity to pre-COVID levels:Contact UsAddress: 35/1 South Street Valletta VLT1100Email: admin@maltaemployers.comTel: 21237585 / 21222992Website: www.maltaemployers.comFacebook: Malta Employers AssociationCOVID-19: TESTING BUSINESS PERFORMANCE, SURVEY
